OB-001.name: Maria Gonzalez
OB-001.chief_complaint: Active labor, regular contractions every 3 minutes

medications.name: penicillin G
medications.dose: 5 million units IV loading, then 2.5 million units q4h

fetal_monitoring.interpretation: Normal Category I tracing, reassuring fetal status

OB-001.correct_diagnosis: Active labor at term, GBS positive requiring intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis
OB-001.correct_management: Continue labor management with continuous fetal monitoring, administer penicillin G for GBS prophylaxis (5 million units IV loading then 2.5 million units q4h until delivery), monitor labor progress, pain management per patient preference, anticipate normal spontaneous vaginal delivery

OB-002.name: Jessica Park
OB-002.chief_complaint: Severe headache, epigastric pain, elevated blood pressure

medications.name: magnesium sulfate
medications.indication: seizure prophylaxis for preeclampsia with severe features

fetal_monitoring.interpretation: Category II tracing with variable decelerations and minimal variability, requires close monitoring

OB-002.correct_diagnosis: Preeclampsia with severe features, concern for HELLP syndrome (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelets)
OB-002.correct_management: Magnesium sulfate 4g IV bolus then 2g/hr for seizure prophylaxis, labetalol IV for acute BP management (target <160/110), administer betamethasone for fetal lung maturation, continuous fetal monitoring, serial labs q6h (CBC, CMP, LDH, coagulation studies), consult MFM, plan delivery within 24-48 hours if no improvement or sooner if maternal/fetal decompensation

OB-003.name: Ashley Williams
OB-003.chief_complaint: Post-dates pregnancy, here for evaluation for induction of labor

fetal_monitoring.interpretation: Reactive NST, Category I tracing, reassuring fetal status

OB-003.correct_diagnosis: Post-dates pregnancy at 41w2d with low Bishop score and low-normal amniotic fluid
OB-003.correct_management: Given post-dates status beyond 41 weeks, induction of labor is indicated. Low Bishop score (4) favors cervical ripening prior to oxytocin. Options: misoprostol 25mcg PV q4h or mechanical (Foley catheter balloon). Monitor AFI closely given borderline low value. Continuous fetal monitoring during induction. Prior SVDs are favorable for successful induction.

OB-004.name: Catherine Chen
OB-004.chief_complaint: Gestational diabetes follow-up, on insulin therapy

medications.name: insulin lispro
medications.dose: 4-8 units SC before meals per sliding scale

OB-004.correct_diagnosis: Gestational diabetes mellitus requiring insulin therapy with suboptimal glycemic control (A1c 6.8%), polyhydramnios, advanced maternal age IVF pregnancy
OB-004.correct_management: Optimize insulin regimen (adjust lispro for post-meal excursions, target fasting <95, 2hr post-prandial <120), continue low-dose aspirin for preeclampsia prophylaxis, serial growth ultrasounds q3-4 weeks for macrosomia surveillance, monitor AFI for worsening polyhydramnios, antenatal testing (NST/BPP) starting 32 weeks, plan delivery at 39 weeks if well-controlled (37-39 if poorly controlled), TSH monitoring per trimester

OB-005.name: Brittany Johnson
OB-005.chief_complaint: First prenatal visit, positive home pregnancy test

medications.name: sertraline
medications.safety_notes: Generally considered compatible with pregnancy; discuss risks/benefits with patient; monitor newborn for neonatal adaptation syndrome

ob_history.LMP: 6 weeks ago by dates, consistent with 8 weeks by early ultrasound

needed_labs: varicella titer if unsure of immunity

fetal_monitoring.note: Transvaginal ultrasound: intrauterine pregnancy with fetal pole measuring 8w0d, fetal heart rate 165 bpm by M-mode

screening_needed.smoking_cessation: 5 As counseling needed (Ask, Advise, Assess, Assist, Arrange)
screening_needed.genetic_screening: first trimester screening offered (NT + PAPP-A + free beta-hCG)

OB-005.correct_diagnosis: Intrauterine pregnancy at 8 weeks, first prenatal visit requiring comprehensive screening. Active tobacco use and depression on sertraline require counseling.
OB-005.correct_management: Order routine first prenatal labs (CBC, type and screen, rubella, HBsAg, HIV, RPR, UA/culture, GC/CT NAAT), offer first trimester genetic screening, administer PHQ-9 for depression screening, discuss sertraline risk-benefit in pregnancy (generally safe, continue with monitoring), provide smoking cessation counseling using 5 As approach, discuss nutrition and weight gain goals, schedule follow-up visits per ACOG guidelines, offer influenza and Tdap vaccines at appropriate gestational ages

OB-006.name: Danielle Thompson
OB-006.chief_complaint: Desires VBAC, here for counseling and birth plan discussion
OB-006.rh_status: Rh negative, RhoGAM administered at 28 weeks

vbac_assessment.estimated_success_rate: lower than standard TOLAC due to 2 prior cesareans
vbac_assessment.uterine_rupture_risk: approximately 0.9-1.8% with two prior low-transverse cesareans
vbac_assessment.contraindications: relative - two prior cesareans; many institutions may decline TOLAC after 2 cesareans

OB-006.correct_diagnosis: Term pregnancy with two prior cesarean deliveries (both low transverse), patient desires trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC/VBAC)
OB-006.correct_management: Shared decision-making discussion: risks of TOLAC after 2 cesareans include uterine rupture (0.9-1.8%), vs risks of repeat cesarean (surgical complications, adhesions, placenta accreta spectrum in future pregnancies). Prior vaginal delivery is favorable prognostic factor. If TOLAC pursued: requires continuous fetal monitoring, immediate availability of OR and anesthesia, informed consent documenting counseling. If repeat cesarean chosen: schedule at 39 weeks. Either approach reasonable depending on institutional capabilities and patient preference.

OB-007.name: Kayla Robinson
OB-007.chief_complaint: Irregular heavy periods for 6 months, fatigue

gyn_complaint.severity: heavy - soaking through pad every 1-2 hours on heaviest days, passing clots

pap_smear.note: Per ASCCP guidelines, initial Pap smear at age 21

OB-007.correct_diagnosis: Abnormal uterine bleeding (menorrhagia) with iron deficiency anemia. Differential includes anovulatory bleeding (most common at age 19), coagulopathy (von Willebrand disease), structural causes (polyp, fibroid). PALM-COEIN classification evaluation needed.
OB-007.correct_management: Complete AUB workup per PALM-COEIN: pregnancy test (done, negative), CBC (anemia confirmed), coagulation studies including VWF panel (rule out von Willebrand), TSH and prolactin (normal), pelvic ultrasound to evaluate structural causes. Treat iron deficiency with oral ferrous sulfate 325mg BID. Offer combined OCP for cycle regulation and bleeding reduction. Pap smear at age 21 per guidelines (patient is 19). Counsel on contraception options. If bleeding refractory, consider tranexamic acid or endometrial biopsy.

OB-008.name: Tamara Jackson
OB-008.chief_complaint: Acute onset severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding

social_history.drugs: history of cocaine use, denies current use

fetal_monitoring.interpretation: Category III tracing: absent variability with recurrent late decelerations, consistent with significant fetal compromise

physical_exam.abdomen: rigid, tender, uterine hypertonus, fundal height greater than dates
physical_exam.cervix: closed, no placenta previa on prior ultrasound

OB-008.correct_diagnosis: Placental abruption with fetal compromise (Category III fetal heart tracing)
OB-008.correct_management: EMERGENT: Activate massive transfusion protocol, two large-bore IVs with fluid resuscitation, type and crossmatch (blood products available), emergent cesarean delivery given Category III tracing (absent variability + recurrent late decelerations). Administer RhoGAM (Rh negative). Betamethasone if any time permits (32 weeks). Notify NICU team for preterm delivery. Continuous maternal hemodynamic monitoring. Monitor for DIC (serial fibrinogen, coags). Urine drug screen. Post-delivery: monitor for postpartum hemorrhage and coagulopathy.

shoulder_dystocia.name: Shoulder Dystocia Management Protocol

steps.details: Call for additional nursing, obstetrician, anesthesia, pediatrics/NICU
Consider episiotomy to provide more room for maneuvers (does not relieve bony obstruction but allows access)
Hyperflexion of maternal hips, thighs to abdomen. Flattens sacral promontory, increases AP diameter of pelvis. Most effective single maneuver.
Apply pressure to suprapubic area to adduct and rotate anterior shoulder under symphysis. Use with McRoberts.
Rubin II: pressure on posterior aspect of anterior shoulder to adduct and rotate. Woods corkscrew: pressure on anterior aspect of posterior shoulder to rotate 180 degrees.
Sweep posterior arm across fetal chest, grasp hand and deliver posterior arm. Reduces shoulder diameter by ~2cm.
Roll patient to all-fours position. Changes pelvic dimensions and may allow disimpaction.

shoulder_dystocia.time_limit: Document time from delivery of head to delivery of body
shoulder_dystocia.documentation: Document time of delivery of head and body, maneuvers used in order, personnel present, neonatal outcome

pph.name: Postpartum Hemorrhage Management Protocol
pph.definition: Blood loss >= 1000mL or signs/symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours of delivery

stages.name: Escalation
actions: Activate PPH protocol / call for help
Carboprost (Hemabate) 250mcg IM q15min (avoid if asthmatic), max 8 doses
Tranexamic acid 1g IV over 10 min (within 3 hours of delivery)
Warm IV fluids, consider blood products

stages.name: Massive Hemorrhage
actions: Surgical interventions: B-Lynch suture, uterine artery ligation, hysterectomy
Interventional radiology: uterine artery embolization if available and stable

pph.causes_mnemonic: 4 Ts: Tone (atony), Trauma (lacerations), Tissue (retained products), Thrombin (coagulopathy)

eclampsia.name: Eclampsia Management Protocol
eclampsia.definition: New-onset seizures in a patient with preeclampsia, not attributable to other causes
immediate_actions: Protect airway - position on left side, suction available
Call for help - obstetrics, anesthesia, nursing
Do NOT attempt to restrain or insert oral airway during seizure
Continuous pulse oximetry, supplemental O2 if SpO2 <95%

blood_pressure_management.first_line: Labetalol 20mg IV, then 40mg, then 80mg q10min (max 300mg total)
blood_pressure_management.third_line: Nicardipine drip 5mg/hr, titrate q5min up to 15mg/hr

eclampsia.delivery_planning: Delivery is definitive treatment. Stabilize mother first, then plan delivery. Mode depends on gestational age, fetal status, and cervical exam.

cord_prolapse.name: Umbilical Cord Prolapse Management Protocol
cord_prolapse.definition: Descent of the umbilical cord through the cervix alongside or past the presenting part

immediate_actions.details: Notify obstetrics, anesthesia, OR staff, NICU
Insert gloved hand into vagina and manually elevate the presenting part off the cord. Do NOT attempt to replace cord.
Steep Trendelenburg or knee-chest position to reduce cord compression
Instill 500-700mL sterile NS via Foley catheter to elevate presenting part
Goal: delivery within 10-15 minutes of diagnosis
If FHR recovers with elevation, continue monitoring en route to OR

do_not: Do NOT attempt to push cord back into uterus
Do NOT remove hand elevating presenting part until delivery
Do NOT delay for betamethasone at viable gestational ages
